reasoning: The critique targets a key enabling assumption for the essay’s comparatively optimistic path (partial AM-convergence + trade), namely that workable institutions can realize large gains from moral trade without being subverted. If institutional capture is the default, that meaningfully reduces how promising the trade/compromise pathway is, but it doesn’t refute the whole position (the essay already entertains other pathways and explicitly lists concentration of power/decision-procedure failures as major blockers). The argument offered is a plausible mechanism (capture of the adjudication/enforcement layer via definitional control and procedural laundering), but it’s more a warning than a demonstrated refutation: it doesn’t engage with countermeasures (decentralization, robust constitutional constraints, competitive governance, cryptographic/commitment mechanisms, adversarial audits, etc.), and it overstates with “immediately captured”/near-inevitability. Still, as a failure mode it’s largely correct and clearly articulated, with minimal fluff and essentially one coherent point.
title: Institutional capture turns moral trade into legitimized domination
